RESIGNATION OF SPEAKER
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


    Mr Speaker: As Honourable Members are aware, I am Speaker of this Assembly by virtue of the provisions of Section 110 of the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council, 1958, and my term of office will expire on June the 2nd of this year, leaving a vacancy in that office as from June the 3rd.

    June the 3rd, however, is National Day and is a holiday, and consequently it would not be convenient for the Assembly to meet on that day to fill that vacancy.

    I therefore intend to resign my office on Wednesday, the 1st of June, so that honourable Members may, if they so desire, sit on that day for the purpose of the election of a person to fill the office of Speaker left vacant by reason of my resignation.

PERMITS GRANTED FOR
RETENTION OF UNAUTHORISED
TEMPORARY HOUSES


    3. Dato Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat asked the Prime Minister under what circumstances will permits be granted for the retention of unauthorised temporary houses, and whether such permits will be granted to unauthorised temporary houses built after 1st June, 1959.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Chan Sun Wing) (for the Prime Minister) (In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, I was asked by the Prime Minister to answer this questions.

    The answer depends upon whether it is State land or private land that is affected.

Column: 535



    As regards State land, the policy is that encroachments will not be permitted under any circumstances. All unauthorised structures on State land are demolished summarily whenever and wherever found. Where unauthorised houses are already in existence, the Government has decided to evict the occupants only in those cases where the land is required immediately for public development. In other cases, and until such time as the land is required for public development, the unauthorised occupation will be regularised by requiring the occupant to pay a fee for a Temporary Occupation Licence. The quantum of the fee is according to a sliding scale, having regard to the area of land occupied, the locality and such other factors. A portion of the fee will be credited to the tenant's account, will accumulate each month, and will be refunded to him when he demolishes the house and vacates the site. All fees are payable with effect from 1st January, 1960.

    Concerning private land, the policy is that action will be taken against all unauthorised houses. As regards unauthorised houses already in existence, permits for retention may be issued under the following conditions only:-

    (i) the land owner's permission has been given to the occupier of the unauthorised structure;

    (ii) the unauthorised house is or can be made structurally sound and does not constitute a fire or health hazard;

    (iii) Court action has not resulted in the issue of a Mandatory Order, and conditions (i) and (ii) have been complied with.

    4. Dato Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat asked the Minister for Finance

Column: 536

what were the total estimated revenue and the total actual revenue for the first three months of 1960.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the hon. Member asked for details of the estimated total revenue and actual total revenue for the first quarter of this year.

    Estimates of revenue are framed on an annual basis and not on a quarterly or monthly basis. The reason is that certain major items of revenue, of which income tax is the outstanding example, are not collected by regular and equal monthly amounts. In the case of income tax collections, for instance, the main harvest will be reaped during the months of June, July and August. The reason is that a time limit is set for the waiting of returns of income, only after which can the Department get down to the raising of assessments. Nevertheless, it does not mean that the Government does not continually examine each item of revenue to see whether or not its performance comes up to expectations.

    In answer to the hon. Member, I can give him two assurances. First, the revenue position for the main items of revenue is satisfactory. Second, all efforts have been made to collect for the State revenue due to it, so that the final outcome will be as envisaged in the Estimates of Revenue, if not better.

    Indeed, we have today before the Assembly the Income Tax (Amendment) Bill which will ensure more effective assessment and collection of income tax. Doubtless I can take it that the concern which the Member has expressed over the collection of State revenue would be more positively expressed in the form of support for the amending Bill.

    As regards the second part of his question, that is, the total revenue for the first quarter of 1960, I submit a table for the information of the Member.

(Registration cancelled)

Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib asked the Minister for Labour and Law whether he is aware that the registration of the Singapore Government Workers Union which was registered in 1951 and had 1,659 members has been cancelled; and whether he will consider reversing the cancellation order made by the Registrar.

    The Union has 30 days within which to appeal, and has submitted its appeal on the 7th May, 1960.

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND
CONTRIBUTIONS


    8. Mr Thio Chan Bee asked the Minister for Labour and Law whether he will consider introducing amending legislation to raise the minimum rate of interest payable on contributions to the Central Provident Fund.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, under the Central Provident Fund Ordinance, the Central Provident Fund Board is obliged to declare a minimum rate of interest of 2½ per cent per annum, and the Board is precluded from declaring any higher rate of interest unless and until the assets of the Fund valued at the current market price exceed its liabilities by ten per cent.

    At present, the Fund's assets at current market prices have not exceeded this limit of ten per cent.

    In the present circumstances, there is no case for considering amending legislation to raise the present minimum rate of interest.
